pages.text: Coronacollina acula comes from the Upper Ediacaran, with fossils found from the Flinders Ranges, South Australia. It is a strange, tri-radial cup-like lifeform with 4 spicules radiating from the centre. With this morphology, it has stumped all paleontologist on what its true taxonomic position should be.
The generic name derives from the Latin words 'corona', to mean 'rim', and 'collis', to mean 'hill'. The specific name derives from the Latin word 'acula', to mean 'needle'.
